content:
Hey folks, maybe you say my blog post, but I wanted to say that I plannned to do some async vision doc writing sessions if anybody wants to join me:

  • 2021-03-23T12:00:00-04:00
  • 2021-03-23T17:00:00-04:00
If this works out well, I'll probably do more.
hmm, i think i'm interested in this!
@Andrew Chin (eminence32) starting now! :)
just set you a zoom url
as a privmsg on zulip? i don't think i see it.... looking around
i got nothing
@Andrew Chin (eminence32) oh
sorry!
I thought I sent it to you, I'll send it now in case you can join
are you still planning for a ~5PM writing session?
yep!
I'm trying to think ahead a bit to what we should work on
what we did in the noon session was to collaboratively write
kind of taking turns with somebody typing and one person "driving" (and others making suggestons)
I ran a timer for like 5 min each :)
the main advantage of alternating who types is it forces people to stay engaged a bit more, and not multitask too badly :)

basically "pair programming"

except we're coding in english, not rust
that said it would be nice to tackle an issue where somebody has personally experineced it if we can

Andrew Chin (eminence32) said:

basically "pair programming"

yes sort of :)
I was thinking of some workshops I did for learning languages where you had one person typing, one person standing up at the front of the room, and the rest of the audience calling out advice
@Andrew Chin (eminence32) if you come, we could do this story
yeah. it takes a certain amount of brain power to convert thought into written words. having others to help with the thinking part makes it easier
ok, sure
I'm going to go through the issues though and pick out some top candidates

a lot of my experiences with async so far (mostly from ~1 year ago) have been of the form of "starting a new project, hitting an annoying bump, and then putting down the project". i haven't really used async "in anger" in a big project yet :)
so i'm happy to talk a bit about that. and i'm happy to also drive the keyboard to take some notes
that sounds perfect--
I'd love to have stories about those bumps!

I'm looking through the issues. Some that seem related:

  • learning async rust for the first time #46
• accidentally mixing two runtimes #47
• bridging sync/async in "hobby code" where you don't care that much #54
• debugging stack traces #69 has a different theme but seems pretty actionable
yeah, i very much think these are related topics
one possible thing to discuss is: how much these these storied be combined into a more general "i'm just learning, but i'm having issues" story
yeah I'm not sure, i think we can combine a lot of it
starting now! =)
ping me for urls
I think version incompatibility with async libraries may be related to those issues above too.
yep

About futures being lazy, Alan would probably find it confusing as he comes from e.g. Javascript, but Barbara would think that it is aligned with the iterator's behavior, after knowing about the future's laziness.
I think that sounds right. Barbara has acquired a lot of "ambient knowledge" over the year, and I suspect she would be familiar with the idea that futures are lazy in rust.
agreed
let's pull that bit of surprising into a different story, maybe?

As an async beginner, I think it will be nice to read the status quo stories. I think that this is going to be an interesting way to learn about async as it is today (and how to get through the common pitfalls).

It feels like being one step ahead of my next async bug, because I would've read about it before committing it :laughing:

nikomatsakis said:

let's pull that bit of surprising into a different story, maybe?

Something like an "async footgun" story?
out of curiosity, @Eduardo Canellas, would you have any interest in writing the story where Alan (or Niklaus, perhaps) learns about .await not starting tasks?
not sure if that matches your background :) just saw you mentioned "as an async beginner"
@Andrew Chin (eminence32) yeah -- I'm thinking about something @Jonathan Turner told me once
that his first impression from making things into async was one of "underwhelming" -- basically he made everything async and use await and the end result was ... sequential code
in order to get any parallelism or even concurrency you need to start using combinators and spawning
that could be part of Barbara's story (@Jonathan Turner is definitely barbara)

nikomatsakis said:

out of curiosity, Eduardo Canellas, would you have any interest in writing the story where Alan (or Niklaus, perhaps) learns about .await not starting tasks?

this story may not be that important, unclear
but I think it's worth telling somehow, mainly (to me) it motivates better lints, docs, etc
hmmm. "async didn't do magic things to my code" is interesting, but feels different from "i hit an async footgun". maybe both are unified by some type of "async expectation mismatch" story?
it may be a different story
I was thinking of it not as part of async footguns
but more as part of the story we were writing today -- which is kind of "async-await has more depth and sharp edges than I realized"
this feels like "and the gain is maybe less than I realized'
@nikomatsakis I think my experience is a mix of Alan and Barbara, actually. I know Rust (but not as long as Barbara does) and I know other languages, like Javascript.
ok, yeah
I'm thinking that I want to schedule writing sessions later this week, but this time I want to announce the themes in advance
I should probably wait until thu/fri given that my schedule tomorrow is fairly full
i'll probably have a draft PR open by then, for the story we worked today. we can review it during the session if we want
awesome
let me look over the issues and think about good topics
(if friday is indeed the next session)

@nikomatsakis how did the sessions go? I've been very busy so far this week (took Monday off and was playing catchup yesterday), but I'm interested in helping with this idea if it's proven effective. Maybe I can do an EU morning session?
I thought they were great
I was going to put some thought into planning more sessions
Hitting more time zones would be really good
